defect.para: This Recall applies to GENESIS model buses built from January 1, 1991 through June 8, 1998 and AmTran RE buses built from May 1, 1995 through June 8, 1998.
American Transportation Corporation (AmTran) has determined that a safety hazard in connection with the headlamp system that relates to motor vehicle safety exists in some AmTran buses.

Problem #1: The fuse or circuit breaker on these vehicles could have inadequate circuit protection size for headlamp high beam operation. Operation of the headlamps on high beam could overload the fuse or circuit breaker causing the loss of headlamps. NOTE: The operation of the headlamps on low beam only does not overload this circuit.
Problem #2: The product graphic located on the chassis fuse panel cover could have 10 ampere specified for circuit "F15" (headlamp circuit). It should specify 20 ampere.

Problem #3: The 20 ampere fuse or 20 ampere circuit breaker on these vehicles could be other than "Type I" 20 ampere circuit breaker. We recommend that this be changed to a 20 ampere "Type I" circuit breaker.

Customers have been notified and instructed to complete and return to AmTran Corporation, postage paid "Authorization for Recall Service" cards. Upon return of the postcards, AmTran Corporation will provide the customer the required parts and instructions for repair. The customer has been requested to contact an authorized dealer and make arrangements to have the subject defects repaired on the vehicle without charge.

svcproc.title: INSPECTION
svcproc.para: FOR PROBLEM #1: Open chassis fuse panel cover and determine if fuse location "F15" (headlamp circuit) has a 20 ampere fuse or 20 ampere circuit breaker installed. If not proceed with repair procedure #1. For identification, the fuse has the number 20 stamped on the front of the fuse and the circuit breaker will have 20A printed on the breaker housing.
FOR PROBLEM #2: Review circuit "F15" (headlamp circuit) on product graphic located on fuse panel door for the correct label. It should read 20A. If not proceed to repair procedure #2.

FOR PROBLEM #3: Open chassis fuse panel cover and determine if fuse location "F15" headlamp circuit has a 20 ampere "Type I" circuit breaker installed. If not proceed with repair procedure #1. For identification, the 20 ampere circuit breaker has T1 and 20A printed on the breaker housing. If this location already has a "Type I" circuit breaker installed, no replacement is required.

svcproc.title: REPAIR PROCEDURES
svcproc.para: FOR PROBLEMS #1 AND #3: To install the new 20 ampere "Type I" circuit breaker in the headlamp circuit:

step1.para: Remove the current protection device (fuse or circuit breaker).
Install the new 20 ampere "Type I" circuit breaker.

svcproc.para: FOR PROBLEM #2: To install the new 20 ampere decal on the product graphic:

item.para: Locate the "10A" at the "F15" location on the product graphic.
Place the "20A" decal over the "10A" letters.

note.para: Operators manual and Service manuals will be updated with their next revision.

entry.para: Install new circuit breaker and apply decal.

responuscan.para:
Proceed immediately to make necessary correction to units in inventory. All inventory vehicles subject to this recall campaign must be corrected prior to sale, transfer or delivery.
If vehicles have been sold or transferred and you are in receipt of Customer Notification Letters and Authorization for Recall Service cards for those vehicles, transfer location or customer must be notified from your dealer location.

The National Traffic and Motor Vehicle Safety Act, as amended, provides that each vehicle that is subject to a vehicle recall campaign must be adequately repaired within a reasonable time after the owner has tendered it for repair. A failure to adequately repair within 60 days after a tender of a vehicle is prima facie evidence of failure to repair within a reasonable time. If the condition is not adequately repaired within 60 days, the owner may be entitled to replacement with an identical or reasonable equivalent vehicle at no charge, or to a refund of the purchase price less a reasonable allowance for depreciation.

In order to avoid having to replace an owner's vehicle or refund the purchase price, every effort must be made to promptly schedule an appointment with each owner to repair their vehicle as soon as possible.
